goal: Get up and running with PyTorch
prerequisites: Basic understanding of machine learning fundamentals

sections.name: PyTorch Fundamentals
sections.description: Introduction to PyTorch's core data structures, operations, automatic differentiation, and basic building blocks for neural networks.

subsections.name: Core Concepts
concepts: Tensors: Introduction to PyTorch's core data structure, tensor creation, data types, and device placement (CPU/GPU)
Tensor Operations: Basic arithmetic, broadcasting, indexing, slicing, and reshaping
Automatic Differentiation (Autograd): Understanding `torch.autograd`, `requires_grad`, `backward()`, and the computation graph
PyTorch Modules (`nn.Module`): Building blocks for neural networks, defining custom layers and models
Optimizers: Introduction to `torch.optim` (e.g., SGD, Adam) and their role in training
Loss Functions: Common loss functions (e.g., `nn.MSELoss`, `nn.CrossEntropyLoss`)

subsections.name: Practical Examples
subsections.description: Hands-on exercises to apply fundamental concepts.
concepts: Creating and manipulating tensors
Performing basic tensor operations
Calculating gradients using `autograd`
Implementing a simple linear regression model from scratch using `nn.Module`, an optimizer, and a loss function

subsections.name: Assessment Tasks
subsections.description: Exercises to test understanding of Module 1.
concepts: Implement a simple function that creates two tensors, performs element-wise multiplication, and computes the gradient of the result with respect to one of the input tensors
Build a basic neural network with one hidden layer using `nn.Module` to solve a binary classification problem on a synthetic dataset

sections.name: Building and Training Neural Networks
sections.description: Covers data handling, specific neural network architectures (CNNs, RNNs), and the complete model training lifecycle.

subsections.name: Network Architectures and Training Workflow
subsections.description: Understanding how to build, train, and manage neural networks.
concepts: Data Loading and Preprocessing: `torch.utils.data.Dataset` and `torch.utils.data.DataLoader` for efficient data handling
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs): Understanding convolutional layers, pooling layers, and their application in image processing
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs): Introduction to RNNs, LSTMs, and GRUs for sequential data
Training Loop: Implementing a complete training and validation loop, including forward pass, backward pass, optimization, and evaluation metrics
Model Saving and Loading: Persisting trained models

subsections.name: Practical Applications
subsections.description: Hands-on exercises for building and training neural networks.
concepts: Loading and preprocessing the MNIST dataset
Building and training a CNN for image classification on MNIST
Implementing a simple RNN for text generation (e.g., character-level prediction)
Saving and loading your trained CNN model

subsections.name: Assessment Tasks
subsections.description: Exercises to test understanding of Module 2.
concepts: Train a CNN on the CIFAR-10 dataset and achieve a reasonable accuracy (e.g., >60%)
Implement a simple LSTM network to predict the next word in a given sequence

sections.name: Advanced PyTorch Concepts and Applications
sections.description: Explores more advanced topics like transfer learning, generative models, deployment, and performance optimization.

subsections.name: Advanced Techniques and Deployment
subsections.description: In-depth concepts for real-world PyTorch applications.
concepts: Transfer Learning: Utilizing pre-trained models (e.g., from `torchvision.models`) for new tasks
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs): Basic understanding of Generator and Discriminator networks
Deployment Considerations: Briefly discuss options for deploying PyTorch models (e.g., ONNX, TorchScript)
GPU Acceleration: Best practices for utilizing GPUs effectively
Debugging and Profiling: Tools and techniques for identifying and resolving issues in PyTorch models

subsections.name: Advanced Practical Examples
subsections.description: Hands-on exercises for advanced PyTorch functionalities.
concepts: Fine-tuning a pre-trained ResNet model for a custom image classification task
Implementing a simple GAN to generate synthetic images
Converting a PyTorch model to TorchScript

subsections.name: Assessment Tasks
subsections.description: Exercises to test understanding of Module 3.
concepts: Build a transfer learning model to classify a small custom image dataset (e.g., dog vs. cat images)
Implement a basic GAN to generate images of a specific style (e.g., MNIST digits)

sections.name: Final Project
sections.description: An opportunity to apply all learned concepts to a comprehensive, end-to-end PyTorch project.

subsections.name: Project Goal and Ideas
subsections.description: Defines the objective of the final project and suggests potential areas.
concepts: Image Style Transfer: Implement a neural style transfer algorithm
Sentiment Analysis: Build a model to classify the sentiment of movie reviews
Object Detection (Simplified): Implement a simplified object detection model (e.g., using a pre-trained backbone and custom head)
Time Series Forecasting: Develop a model to predict future values in a time series dataset

subsections.name: Project Deliverables
subsections.description: Specifies what needs to be submitted for the final project.
concepts: Well-documented PyTorch code
A clear explanation of your model architecture, training process, and results
(Optional) A simple web interface or demonstration of your project

sections.name: Resources
sections.description: Supplementary materials to aid in learning PyTorch.

subsections.name: Recommended Resources
subsections.description: A list of valuable external resources for continuous learning and support.
concepts: Official PyTorch Documentation: The ultimate reference for all things PyTorch
PyTorch Tutorials: Excellent official tutorials covering various topics
Online Courses: Look for courses on platforms like Coursera, Udacity, or fast.ai for structured learning
Community Forums: Engage with the PyTorch community on forums and Stack Overflow for support
